diff_hunk:
@@ -4,13 +4,20 @@ class Conference < ActiveRecord::Base
 
   has_many :attendances, dependent: :destroy
   has_many :attendees, through: :attendances, source: :user
-  validates :name, :round, presence: true
+  validates :name, :round, :starts_on, :ends_on, presence: true
+  validate :chronological_dates
 
   accepts_nested_attributes_for :attendances
 
   scope :ordered, ->(sort = {}) { order([sort[:order] || 'starts_on, name', sort[:direction] || 'asc'].join(' ')) }
   scope :in_current_season, -> { where(season: Season.current) }
 
+  def chronological_dates
+    unless [starts_on, ends_on].all?.present? && (starts_on < ends_on)
body:
Just out of curiosity, what's the benefit of putting both values in an array? Isn't
```ruby
unless starts_on && ends_on && (starts_on < ends_on)
```
Doing exactly the same?
